0.title: Simplr Router
0.headline: Simplr Router
0.body:
A small and effective routing solution for Web Components 


  
    Follow Guides 
  
    Browse Docs

1.title: Simplr Router
1.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
1.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

2.title: Simplr Router
2.headline: Small
2.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

3.title: Simplr Router
3.headline: Easy to transition into
3.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

4.title: Simplr Router
4.headline: Web Component focused
4.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

5.title: Simplr Router
5.headline: Customizable
5.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

6.title: Simplr Router
6.headline: Performant
6.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

40.title: Recipes: Lazy loading
40.headline: Bundlers
40.body:
Due to the nature of the import being in code, most bundlers should be able to grasp onto the import statement
and bundle it correctly, even if the file gets renamed.

a.title: Getting started: Using a starter
a.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
a.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

b.title: Getting started: Using a starter
b.headline: Initial setup
b.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
 What would you like to do today?  Scaffold a new project
 What would you like to scaffold?  Application
 What would you like to add? 
 Would you like to use typescript?  No
 What is the tag name of your application/web component?  simplr-router-demo

c.title: Getting started: Using a starter
c.headline: Installing the router
c.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

d.title: Getting started: Using a starter
d.headline: Configuring History API fallback

f.title: Getting started: Using a starter
f.headline: Creating your initial routing

g.title: Getting started: Using a starter
g.headline: Adding views
g.body:
Next we will want to do some actual routing. This requires a few steps: 

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

k.title: Getting started: Using a starter
k.headline: Next steps
k.body:
You're now all set to start building your application on top of Simplr Router. For more configuration
options and recipes, check out the recipes  section. For a thorough look into the actual API
behing Simplr Router, check out the docs .

1s.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1s.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1s.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users.

2s.title: Recipes: Child routes

2t.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2t.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2t.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 

  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

3u.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
3u.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
3u.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .
